solution.explanation: Banabhatta - His teacher's name was Bhatsu or Bharvu. Banabhatta's three works are famous - “Harshacharita”, “Kadambari” and “Chandishtak”. Harshvardhan was the ruler of the Pushyabhuti dynasty of Thaneshwar.

question: Who among the following Navratnas from Chandragupta II court wrote 'Mantrashastra’ ? SSC MTS 12/05/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Vetala Bhatta. Nine jewels (Navratna) of Chandragupta II - Amarasimha, Dhanvantari, Harisena, Kalidasa, Kshapanaka, Shanku, Varahamihira, Varuchi, Vetala-Bhatta.

question: The reign of Kumaragupta I the son and successor of _____ was one of peace and relative inactivity. SSC MTS 13/06/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Chandragupta II (successor of Samudragupta). Kumaragupta I : He was also known as Shakraditya and Mahendraditya. He founded Nalanda Mahavihara in 5th century CE. His successor - Skandagupta.

question: Which king was shown on his coins as a Veena player? SSC MTS 14/06/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Samudragupta - He was a ruler of the Gupta dynasty. On several of his coins, he was depicted as seated on a sofa and playing a Veena. He is known as the Napoleon of India. He was given the title of Kaviraj.

question: After the victory over Sakas, who among the following adopted the title of 'Vikramaditya"? SSC MTS 20/06/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Chandragupta II - He was the son of Samudragupta and Datta Devi. He ruled the Gupta Empire from 380 to 415 AD during the Golden Age of India. He established the Mehrauli iron pillar.

question: Who among the following succeeded Ghatotkacha, the Gupta ruler? SSC MTS 20/06/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Chandragupta I. Founder - Sri Gupta, Next Successors - Ghatotkacha, Chandragupta I, Samudragupta, Chandragupta II, Kumaragupta I (founded Nalanda University).

question: Ruler of which dynasty built the famous Iron pillar in Delhi? SSC CHSL 10/03/2023 (4th Shift)

solution.explanation: Gupta dynasty. In Mehrauli (Delhi) an iron pillar was constructed by the famous king Chandragupta II, India, notable for the rust-resistant composition of the metal used in its construction. The inscription on the pillar is in Sanskrit, about Gupta emperor Chandragupta II.

question: Which of the following oﬃces was NOT held by the poet Harishena? SSC CGL 03/12/2022 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Nagara-shreshthi (Chief banker or merchant). Oﬃces held by Poet Harishena: Maha-danda-Nayaka (Chief Judicial Oﬃcer), Kumar-amatya (Important minister) and a sandhi - vigrahika (Minister of War and Peace).

question: Fa Xian began his journey back home from which of the following Indian state? SSC CGL 08/12/2022 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Bengal. Fa-Xian (Chinese traveller) started his journey back home from Bengal by boarding a merchant ship. He traveled from China to India on foot to acquire Buddhist texts. He came to India, under the reign of Chandragupta II, and arrived at Pataliputra from the northwest.

question: Samudragupta's mother belonged www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle History to which of the following gana? SSC CGL 13/12/2022 (4th Shift)

solution.explanation: Licchavi. Samudragupta (335 -375 CE, Kaviraja) was the son of Chandragupta I and Queen Kumaradevi (Licchavi clan). He is called ‘Napoleon of India’ by V.A. Smith.

question: In the context of Gupta administration, the term 'vithi' referred to a/an: SSC MTS 05/10/2021 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Administrative unit. In Gupta's period, there was a hierarchy of administrative divisions from top to bottom. The empire was called by various names such as Rajya, Rashtra, Desha, Mandala, Prithvi, and Avani. It was divided into provinces, which were further divided into Vishayas. A Vishayapati administered the Vishaya. A part of the Vishaya was called Vithi.

question: Who among the following Gupta rulers married a girl from the Lichchhavi clan? SSC MTS 08/10/2021 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Chandragupta-I. The Lichchhavi clan was headquartered at Vaishali in present-day Bihar during the time of Gautama Buddha. Vardhana Dynasty

question: Which of the following plays was NOT written by Harshavardhana ? SSC CGL 12/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Vikramorvasiyam is a romantic play written by Kalidasa, based on the legend of King Pururava and an Apsara named Urvashi. Kalidasa's works include: Abhijnanasakuntalam, Malavikagnimitram, Kumarasambhavam.

question: Pulakeshin II assumed the title of ‘Dakshinapatheshvara’ (lord of the south) after defeating which of the following rulers of north India? SSC CGL 25/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Harshavardhana (606-647 AD) belonged to the Pushyabhuti dynasty, also known as the Vardhana dynasty. He wanted to extend his power in the Deccan but he was defeated by Pulakesin II, the Chalukya ruler, on the bank of river Narmada. The river thus became the southern boundary of his kingdom. Vardhana dynasty: Founder - Pushyabhuti. Capital: Thanesar (Thaneshwar), later Kannauj (Kanyakubja).

question: Pushyabhuti dynasty, after Prabhakarvardhana, strengthened its position in the regions of Punjab and Haryana after defeating which of the following dynasties? SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Hunas. The Pushyabhuti dynasty (Vardhana dynasty) ruled northern India during the 6th and 7th centuries, emerging after the Gupta Empire's decline. Its core territory was in present-day Haryana, with Sthanishvara (Thaneshwar) as the capital. The dynasty reached its peak under Harsha Vardhana, who reigned from 606 to 647 AD.

question: Thaneswar where the Vardhana dynasty ruled around the present-day state of _______. Matriculation Level 20/06/2024 (Shift - 4)

solution.explanation: Haryana.

question: According to which of the following foreign travellers did Dhruvasena II attend Harsha’s assembly at Prayag (Allahabad)? SSC CGL Tier II 26/10/2023

solution.explanation: Hiuen Tsang (Xuanzang) - Chinese Buddhist monk who travelled from China to India to study Buddhism and obtain Buddhist scriptures during the reign of King Harsha Vardhan. Assembly of Prayag (Maha Moksha Parishad) - Harsha Vardhan gave all his belongings in charity for the welfare of the public.

question: Who sent an envoy to the Chinese court in 641 AD? SSC Stenographer 13/10/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Harsha Vardhan. In 641 AD Harshavardhan sent an envoy to Taizong (Tai-Tsung), the Tang emperor of China and in return, the Chinese ruler sent three embassies to Harsha court.

question: After about 75 years of Harshavardhana's death ______ rose to power in Kannauj. SSC Stenographer 13/10/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Yashovarman. He was the founder of the Varman dynasty of Kanauj and surrounding areas during the 8th and the 9th centuries.

question: What was the period of Harshavardhana's reign? SSC CGL 25/07/2023 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: 606 CE to 647 CE. Harshavardhana - Last ruler of the Vardhana Empire (Pushyabhuti dynasty); Undisputed ruler of Thaneshwar (modern -day Haryana). He was author of three Sanskrit plays - Nagananda, Ratnavali, Priyadarshika.

question: King Shashanka, against whom Harshvardhana declared war, was a ruler of the ______ kingdom. SSC MTS 14/10/2021 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Gauda. Karnasubarna was the capital of Gauda Kingdom during the reign of Shashanka, the ﬁrst important king of ancient Bengal who ruled in the 7th century. Chola Dynasty

question: With reference to medieval history, consider the following statements. 1. The founder of the Chola dynasty called the ‘Imperial Cholas’ was Vijayalaya (9th century AD). 2. One of the important dynasties which ruled in northern India was Gurjara-Pratiharas. 3. Palas ruled in western India and Rashtrakutas ruled in southern India in the early years (750 -1000). Which of the given statement(s) is/are correct? SSC MTS 12/11/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: 1 and 2 only. The successors of Vijayalaya expanded the Chola kingdom by annexing Pandyan and Pallava territories. Rajaraja I, who became king in 985, strengthened and reorganized the empire. His son, Rajendra I, further extended the Chola inﬂuence with expeditions to the Ganga valley, Sri Lanka, and Southeast Asia, supported by a powerful navy. Palas ruled in eastern India and Rashtrakutas ruled in the Deccan region.

question: One of the greatest of Chola rulers, Rajaraja I ruled from 985 AD to ______. SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: 1014 AD. The Chola Empire was founded by Vijayalaya. Rajaraja I was known for his conquests of South India and parts of Sri Lanka. He built the great Brihadisvara Temple at the Chola capital Thanjavur.

question: Which of the following animals was the emblem of the Chola dynasty? SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Tiger. Three dynasties ruled during the Sangam Age. Cheras: Modern-Day City (Kerala), Ancient Capital (Vanji), Important Ports (Musiri, Tondi), Emblem (Bow and Arrow). Cholas: Modern-Day City (Tamil Nadu), Ancient Capital (Uraiyur, Puhar), Important Ports (Kaveripattinam). Pandyas: Modern-Day City (Tamil Nadu), Ancient Capital (Madurai), Important Ports {Muziris (Muchiri), Korkai, Kaveri}, Emblem (Carp).

question: Brihadiswara Temple of Tanjore was built by which of the following Chola emperors? SSC CHSL 04/07/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Raja Raja Chola. The Brihadisvara Temple (Dravidian-style) also known as Raja Rajeswara Temple is dedicated to Shiva. It was declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1987.

question: Which among the following Chola emperors defeated the Pandya king Maravarman Rajsimha II in the battle of Vellore? SSC CHSL 05/07/2024 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Parantaka I. Rajaraja I, the son of Parantaka II, is the most celebrated of the Chola kings and ascended the throne in 985 AD. Rajendra I, the son of Rajaraja I, became the ﬁrst Chola king to venture to the banks of the Ganges, earning the title "Victor of the Ganges."

question: Name the Chola inscription that provided details of the way in which the sabha was organised in the local administration in the Chola empire. SSC CHSL 08/07/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Uttaramerur inscription. It dated 919 CE and 921 CE of the Chola king Parantaka I provides evidence of India's long history of democratic government.

question: In the 11th century, the army of which of the following Cholas reached upto Ganga to invade Bengal? SSC CHSL 04/08/2023 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Rajendra I (1014 and 1044 CE) - He was also known as Gangaikonda Chola. He defeated Mahipala, the Pala king of Bengal and Bihar.

question: Who among the following rulers invaded Malaya to liberate their trade with China? SSC CHSL 07/08/2023 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Chola dynasty.

question: Sabha and Ur, two kinds of village assemblies are referred to in which of the following dynasties? SSC CGL 20/07/2023 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Chola. Ur - Assembly of common villagers. Sabha - Assembly in the villages which were inhabited predominantly by the Brahmanas. Nagaram - Assembly of merchants, traders and artisans.

question: "Brahmadeya", a type of land during the Chola Period was the ________. SSC MTS 10/05/2023

solution.explanation: Land gifted to Brahmans. There were ﬁve types of 'land gifts' that Chola kings gave to their people on the basis of Chola inscriptions : Vellanvagai - For non-Brahmana, peasant proprietors. Shalabhoga - For the maintenance of a school. Devadana or Tirunamattukkani - Land gifted to temples. Pallichchhandam - Land donated to Jaina institutions.

question: The Airavatesvara Temple in Tamil Nadu was built by _________ . SSC MTS 14/06/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Rajaraja Chola II. Airavatesvara Temple is a Hindu temple built in the Dravidian style of architecture. Dedicated to - Lord Shiva.

question: The term "Vetti" in Chola empire is related to ___________ SSC MTS 14/06/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Forced labour. Some types of taxes in Cholas empire: Kadmai or Irai - Tax on land; Pattam and ayam - Taxes imposed on non-agricultural professions like artisans and merchants; Nirvilai or nirkkirai - Water tax; Ulku and sungam - Toll tax; Tattar-pattam - A tax levied on gold -smiths; Sangam - Export and import taxes; Kannala Kanam - Marriage tax; Poorvi - War tax.

question: Sultan Mahmud of Ghazni was a contemporary of which Chola king? SSC CGL 02/12/2022 (4th Shift)

solution.explanation: Rajendra I who ruled from 1014 to 1044 CE. Ghazni invaded India seventeen times. In 1018 he plundered the holy city of Mathura and also attacked Kannauj.

question: In the early eleventh century, the Chola king Rajendra I built a Shiva temple and ﬁlled it with a Sun-pedestal seized from the ______. SSC CGL 03/12/2022 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Chalukyas. Chola king Rajendra-I (reigned between 1014 and 1044 CE) built a Shiva temple in his capital, Gangaikondacholapuram (north Tamil Nadu) and ﬁlled it with prized statues seized from defeated rulers such www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle History as Sun-pedestal (Chalukyas), a Ganesha statue and several statues of Durga, a Nandi statue, an image of Bhairava and Bhairavi (Kalingas of Orissa), and a Kali statue (Palas of Bengal).

question: Who among the following belonged to the ancient chieﬂy family of the Cholas from Uraiyur, captured the Kaveri delta from the Muttaraiyar in the middle of the ninth century ? SSC CGL 06/12/2022 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Vijayalaya founded the Chola Empire and captured Thanjavur (Capital of Chola Empire) in 850 CE. He constructed a temple for the goddess Nishumbhasudini in Thanjavur.

question: Which of the following towns was grown as a temple town during the Chola dynasty? SSC CGL 08/12/2022 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Bhillasvamin. Famous Chola dynasty temples: Moovar Koil (Kodumbalur), Koranganatha (Musiri), Valisvara Temple, Kampaheswarar Temple (Thirubuvanam). All temples mentioned above are in Tamil Nadu.

question: Which of the following territories to the south and north were made part of the Chola kingdom by the successors of the ruler Vijayalaya? SSC CGL 09/12/2022 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Pandaya and Pallava. The Pallava dynasty (275 CE to 897 CE, Capital - Kanchipuram) ruled in Deccan (Tondaimandalam). Pandya (Capital - Madurai). The Cheras (Capital - Vanji), Greatest ruler of Cheras - Senguttuvan, also known as Red Chera.

question: Which dynasty bronze statues were made using the "lost wax" technique? SSC CGL 12/12/2022 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Chola. Bronze is an alloy of copper and tin. The lost wax technique is a method of metal casting in which molten metal is poured into a mold that has been created by means of a wax model. Examples: Nataraja Bronze Casting, Shiva and Parvati (Sivagami, 1012 CE), etc.

question: Puhar or Kaveripattinam, was the port of which of the following dynasty? SSC CGL 13/12/2022 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Cholas (8th-12th century AD) was founded by Vijayalaya in the 8th century. Rajaraja Chola (greatest king of the Chola Empire) reigned between 985 and 1014 C.E. Miscellaneous

question: With which of the following relief sculptures were the walls of the great Stupa of Amaravati in the Lower Godavari region adorned? SSC Stenographer 10/12/2024 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Bas relief. The Amaravati school of art ﬂourished under the patronage of the Satavahanas in the Andhra region. Nagarjunkonda, another notable site, is renowned for its Buddhist architecture.

question: Select the correct alternative on the given statements based on Ashoka's Lion capital and India's State Emblem. Statement I: In the original Ashoka's Lion Capital, there are four lions mounted back- to-back on a circular abacus that itself rests on a bell-shaped lotus. Statement II: The State Emblem is an adaptation of the Lion Capital of Asoka at Sarnath in which the bell-shaped lotus was omitted. SSC Stenographer 10/12/2024 (Morning)

options.B: Both Statement I and Statement II are
options.C: Neither Statement I nor Statement II

solution.correct_answer: B. Both Statement I and Statement II are
solution.explanation: Both Statement I and statement II are true. The Lion Capital of Ashoka, carved around 250 BCE, is the head of a column erected by Emperor Ashoka at Sarnath, near Varanasi, India. Ashoka, the 3rd ruler of the Mauryan Empire (c. 268–232 BCE), governed a vast territory that stretched from present-day Afghanistan to Bangladesh, with Pataliputra as its capital.

question: Sun temple at Modhera was built by which of the following rulers? SSC Stenographer 10/12/2024 (Evening)

options.C: Krishna Deva Raya (d) Raja Bhimdev I

solution.explanation: Raja Bhimdev I. He was a Chaulukya king who ruled parts of present-day Gujarat, India. The Sun Temple of Modhera, dedicated to the solar deity Surya, is located in Modhera village, Mehsana district, Gujarat, on the bank of the river Pushpavati.

question: Kautilya has mentioned the concept of Saptanga Rajya to understand the State with seven organs and one of them is Danda, which means: SSC Stenographer 11/12/2024 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Force. Kautilya, also known as Chanakya, outlined the Saptanga theory of the state in the Arthashastra, identifying seven key components: Swami (King), Amatya (Minister), Janapada (Territory), Durga (Fort), Kosa (Treasure), Danda (Army or Force), and Mitra (Ally).

question: The Dhakeshwari Temple in present day Bangladesh has been constructed under the rule of which dynasty? SSC Stenographer 11/12/2024 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Sena. The National Temple of Bangladesh is the Dhakeshwari Temple, located in the capital, Dhaka. Dhakeshwari means "Goddess of Dhaka" and was built in the 12th century by King Ballal Sen of the Sena dynasty.

question: Nataraja represents the dancing ﬁgure of which Hindu deity? SSC CHSL Tier II 18/11/2024

solution.explanation: Shiva. Nataraja is a depiction of Shiva performing the cosmic dance of creation and destruction, known as the Tandava, while surrounded by ﬂames.

question: The excavated ruins of the Nalanda University indicate that bright red _____ was/were used in its construction. SSC MTS 18/10/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: bricks. The Ancient Nalanda University was founded by Kumaragupta I. Nalanda University was destroyed in 1193 CE by Bakhtiyar Khilji, a Turkish military general. The Chinese scholars I-Qing and Xuan Zang visited Nalanda in the 7th century CE. The ancient Nalanda was a centre of learning from the 5th century CE to 12th century CE. Located in present day Rajgir, Bihar. www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle History

question: Who excavated the Chira Tope stupa at Taxila? SSC MTS 23/10/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: John Marshall. Dharmarajika Stupa in Taxila, Pakistan is also known as Chir Tope, which means "Scarred hill".

question: Which among the following dynasties originated from the Yueh-chih tribe of China? SSC MTS 14/11/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Kushanas. They migrated from China to Bactria, then to areas of Afghanistan and ﬁnally into India around the 1st century CE.

question: Details about Sudarshana lake are given in a rock inscription at Girnar (Junagarh), which was composed to record the achievements of the Shaka ruler _________. SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Rudradaman I. Junagadh inscription is written in the Sanskrit language. It is located near Girnar hill near Junagadh in Gujarat. The Junagadh rock contains inscriptions of Ashoka (one of the fourteen Major Rock Edicts of Ashoka), Rudradaman I and Skandagupta.

question: Silappathikaram (the Jewelled Anklet), the earliest epic poem in Tamil was written in the 5th - 6th Century CE by _________. SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Ilango Adigal. Ancient Tamil literature is known as Sangama Literature. The Sangam literature includes Tolkappiyam, Ettutogai, Pattuppattu, Pathinenkilkanakku, and two epics named – Silappathikaram, and Manimegalai (Written by Sittalai Sattanar). The earliest known work in ancient Tamil is Agastyam.

question: In the 7th Century AD, a new religion called Islam was born in _______ . SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Arabia. Prophet Muhammad established Islam. He was born around 570 AD in Mecca. In 622 AD, he completed the Hegira, his migration from Mecca to Medina, to escape persecution.

question: Gautamiputra Satakarni titled Rajaraja and Maharaja is related to which of the following dynasties? SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: The Satavahana Dynasty, founded by Simuk, primarily encompassed present-day Andhra Pradesh, Maharashtra, and Telangana, along with portions of Gujarat, Karnataka, and Madhya Pradesh.

question: Valabhi, a city of ancient India was the capital of the __________ dynasty from the 5th to 8th Century CE. SSC CGL 11/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Maitraka. The Maitraka dynasty was founded by Senapati Bhatarka. The decline of the Gupta Empire led to the rise of various ruling dynasties across northern India. Among the most notable were the Pushyabhutis of Thanesar, the Maukhari of Kanauj, and the Maitrakas of Valabhi.

question: Vasudeva I who issued coins in gold (dinars and quarter dinars) and copper (single denomination) was a ________ king. SSC CGL 11/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Kushana. Vasudeva I was the last of the "Great Kushans." He ruled in Northern India and Central Asia, where he minted coins in the city of Balkh. The Kushana dynasty was founded by Kujula Kadphises.

question: Who among the following is the hero of the Sanskrit historical poem, the 'Ramacharita' written by Sandhyakar Nandi? SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Ramapala was the successor to the Pala king Shurapala II in the Bengal region of the Indian subcontinent, and 15th ruler of the Pala line. Sandhyakar Nandi was patronaged by Madanapala, ruler of Pala Dynasty.

question: Vindhyashakti was the founder of which of the following dynasties? SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Vakataka dynasty originated from the Deccan in the mid-3rd century CE. Vakatakas were the most important successors of the Satavahanas in the Deccan and coexistent with the Guptas in northern India.

question: An inscription, Takht-i-Bahi recovered from Mardan near Peshawar, indicates the rule of which of the following dynasties in north-western area of present Pakistan? SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Parthians (247 BC - 224 AD). It was founded by Arsaces I of Parthia when he rebelled against the Seleucid Empire. They replaced the Sakas in North-Western India. The Takht-i-Bahi inscription, dated in 45 AD, refers to Gondophernes as a Parthian ruler.

question: The Maukharis ruled over which of the following cities in western Uttar Pradesh that over the time replaced Pataliputra as a political centre of north India? SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Kannauj. The Maukharis, initially vassals of the Guptas and titled Samantas, gained independence in the mid-6th century as the Gupta Empire declined.

question: Under which of the following Pala king's patronage the Vikramshila university in 8th century India was founded? SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Dharmapala, the second ruler of the Pala Dynasty, ascended the throne around 780 AD after Gopala and expanded the empire signiﬁcantly. He defeated Indrayudha of Kanauj, installing Chakrayudha as his nominee, but later faced defeat by Rashtrakuta king Dhruva near Monghyr, Bihar.

question: Three Poets Pampa, Ponna and Ranna are called as the ‘Three Jewels’ of: SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Kannada Literature. Pampa, also known as Adi Pampa, is renowned for his literary works, including "Vikramarjuna Vijaya" and "Adi Purana." Ponna, often referred to as Ponna Kavishwara, served as a court poet for Rashtrakuta king Krishna III and is best known for his epic "Shantipurana." Ranna was a court poet of the Western Chalukya Empire, and his most celebrated work is "Gadayuddha."

question: Which of the following kingdoms was divided into subdivisions called Aharas or Rashtras that meant districts? SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Satavahana : Period : 60 BC - 225 AD; Capital - Pratishthana (Paithan) and Amravati; Founder - Simuka. The lowest level of administration was a grama which was under the charge of a Gramika. There were also oﬃcers called amatyas who were perhaps ministers or advisors of the king. Revenue was collected both in cash and kind. It majorly comprised present Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, and Maharashtra.

question: ______, authored by Tolkappiyar is the earliest Tamil literature. SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Tolkappiyam. Tamil has a literary tradition that goes back to the period of the Sangams. The most well-known surviving works from this period are the Tolkappiyam (a book of grammar attributed to Tolkappiyar), Ettu Togai (Eight Anthologies), Pattu Pattu (Ten Idylls).

question: The Pandya Kingdom was ﬁrst mentioned by Megasthenes, who said that their kingdom was famous for pearls. Their capital was : SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Madurai. Megasthenes: A Greek diplomat and historian who mentioned the Pandya Kingdom in his book Indica around 300 BCE. The Pandya Kingdom was an ancient Tamil kingdom that ruled parts of southern India, especially Tamil Nadu, from the 6th century BCE to the 15th century CE.

question: In peninsular India, which of the following kingdoms was the local power that ruled over northern Maharashtra and Vidarbha? SSC CGL 19/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Vakatakas. Vindhyashakti founded the Vakataka dynasty in the third century. Their history is mainly known through land grant charters issued to Brahmanas. The Maukhari dynasty ruled over (modern day) Uttar Pradesh and parts of Bihar.

question: In 10th century India, Queen Didda became the ruler of which of the following regions of north India? SSC CGL 19/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Kashmir. Didda was the ruler of Kashmir from 980 CE to 1003 CE. Most knowledge relating to Didda is obtained from the Rajatarangini. Ashish Kaul's novel Didda: The Warrior Queen of Kashmir is based on Didda's life.

question: Mahendravarman I who wrote Mattavilasa-prahasana is related to which of the following ruling dynasties? SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Pallava dynasty (275 CE to 897 CE) - They ruled a signiﬁcant portion of the Deccan, also known as Tondaimandalam, which covered parts of present-day Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh. Founder - Simha Vishnu (Avanisimha).

question: The Pratiharas who ﬁrst had their capital at Bhinmal gained prominence during the rule of: SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Nagabhatta I (Reign : 730 - 760 AD) laid the foundation of the Pratihara dynasty's power. He is best known for defeating the Arabs during their expansion and building an empire that stretched from Gujarat to Gwalior, stopping further Arab invasions in eastern Sindh.

question: According to the inscriptions, Pushyamitra Shunga was a devotee of which of the following Gods? SSC CGL 25/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Krishna. Pushyamitra Shunga founded the Shunga Empire after assassinating the last Mauryan emperor, Brihadratha Maurya. He ruled from 184 BC to 75 BC, driving out the Greeks through the Shunga-Greek war. The capital of the Shunga Empire was Pataliputra.

question: In which of the following temples will you ﬁnd Gopurams? SSC CGL 13/08/2021(Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Shiva Temple, Chidambaram. A gopuram or gopura is a monumental tower, usually ornate, at the entrance of any temple, especially in Southern India. question: Who among the following wrote the basic text of Vaisheshika philosophy? SSC CGL 17/08/2021 (Morning)

question: When was the All India Trade Union Congress (AITUC) established? SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: 1920. All India Trade Union Congress (AITUC) was formed in Bombay. The AITUC was a broad-based organisation involving diverse ideologies. question: Who founded the Theosophical Society in New York in 1875? SSC CGL 25/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

options.B: Baba Dayal Das and Madan Lal

question: What gave a major impetus to the cotton textile industry in India after Independence? SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

Francisco de Almeida was appointed as the ﬁrst Portuguese governor in India. His policy is known for implementing the "Policy of Blue Water," which aimed to establish Portuguese dominance in maritime trade.
